With this template, you can use `CSS` for paged document (pdf).

## Top level variables

### Compulsory variable: `lang`

There is only one compulsory variable: `lang` that defines the language of the document.  
See the [language variables section](http://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#language-variables) of the `pandoc` documentation.

### Papersize

The `papersize` variable control the size of the pages. You can use:

- a well-known size: `a4`, `letter`... 
You can add `landscape` for orientation, for instance: `"a5 landscape"`.
- a customized size: `"4in 6in"`...

### Margins

There is no `geometry` option. In order to control the margins, you have to use `margin-top`, `margin-right`, `margin-bottom` and `margin-left` variables.

### Font size

The `fontsize` variable control the main size of the font for the document. Its default value is `11pt`.

### Line spacing

The line spacing is controlled by the `lineheight` variable. It replaces the `linestretch` variable of `pdf_document`.  
The default value is 1. If you want double line spacing, you can set the `lineheight` value to 2.

### Using a `sans-serif` main font

The defaut main font is a `serif` font. If you prefer a `sans-serif` font, you can add the `sans-serif: true` option to the `YAML` header.

### Specify `mainfont`

With `mainfont`, you can change the main font for the document.

### Specify `monofont`

You can change `monofont`.

### monofontsize

### Text alignment

The text is justified by default. You can modify this behavior with the `textalign` variable. See values in CSS specifications.

### Page counter

You can add page counter with the `pagecounter` variable

## Built-in classes

The `weasydoc::wpdf_document` provides a set of built-in classes. They can be overridden with a customized `CSS` style.

### Paper orientation

You can add the class `portrait` or `landscape` to change the orientation.

For instance, the following `data.frame` will be print in landscape mode.

    `r ''````{r echo=FALSE, class.output="landscape"}
    mtcars
    ```

```{r echo=FALSE, class.output="landscape"}
mtcars
```
